section-block.rac_book_summary: Eliot dreams of adventures. He pretends to track wild animals and sail high seas. When his grandfather comes home, Eliot sets off to find a real adventure.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about pretend games that let them use their imaginations. What do they like to pretend to do? Do they ever pretend they are on a big adventure?
Invite children to dance to the PreK On My Way™ theme music to build excitement for being on a great adventure.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we’re going to read The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra.
Scout enjoys all sorts of books, but he especially likes narratives like this one. He loves adventure stories!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What did Eliot pretend to do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Eliot like to do for fun? What is his idea of an adventure?
How do you know Eliot is pretending? Is he having fun on his adventure? How do you know? What do you like to pretend to do?
Did Eliot find a real wild beast?
What makes you think so?
What changes for Eliot on this page? Why does the dog look different on this page and on page 5?
Do you think Eliot and his grandfather are really sailing their boat or pretending? What clues make you say that?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What did Eliot pretend to do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He pretended to sail the high seas.
He pretended to track wild beasts.
He pretended to stalk a paper dragon.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about things children may like to pretend to do, as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Eliot pretend to do?
Eliot pretended to s_____ (sail) the high seas.
Eliot pretended to sail the high seas.
How do you know that Eliot was pretending?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: The Need for Pretend Play
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research has shown that pretend play is a vital component of social and cognitive growth in the preK years. Pretend play helps to expand children’s vocabulary, language, and creativity. Role playing also improves social skills, including communication, problem solving, empathy, and the ability to share another’s perspective.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Persist in Tasks
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about how we can do so much when we learn to persist in tasks. Elicit from children that when we persist in doing something, we don’t give up. Ask children to share examples of times they persisted to learn something new. What was the task they were working on? How did they persist? Were they able to do it?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the Mind Builder persist in tasks as we revisit the book The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra.
Clifford loves reading stories about persisting in tasks to learn new things. Clifford likes to keep trying until he learns how to do something new.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and look at pages of the book that show the persist in tasks Mind Builder in action. Then we’ll talk about it.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see that has a bow on it? Why might it have a bow on it?

What adventures did El Capitán tell Eliot about? What wild animal does El Capitán see? Do you think the alligator can hurt him? What danger is there for El Capitán in the deep sea? Do you think persistence helps him stay safe? (MB)
Why do you think El Capitán looks sad? What might Eliot be thinking? (MB)
What is Eliot’s new idea? How does Eliot show that he is persisting in a task? (MB)
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit the new idea Vocabulary Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the problem with the boat? How does Eliot think he can solve the problem? (MB)
How does Eliot persist to have an adventure? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Create a worksheet for children with the words “I can ____.” repeated three times and the words “I can’t ____ yet.” on the bottom. Have children draw or write three things they can do.

Then have children draw or write something they can’t do yet. Have children share their work with their classmates. Lead a discussion about how people can learn new things if they persist. Include the idea that everyone has some things they can’t yet do. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about things they can do when they persist. Encourage them to use their imagination.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: You can help children learn to persist by providing lots of activities that involve solving problems with more than one solution. Support children’s independence, and resist the urge to fix a problem so that children see that they can solve the problem independently. Provide gentle guidance if frustration sets in. (Reed and Young, 2017)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children to pay special attention to the important things the author tells them.
Have children sing “Row Your Boat” as they pretend to row a boat. Then replace “row” with “sail” as they pretend to hold sails. Then use “steer” as they pretend to steer.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra. Let’s say the name of the book together, The Greatest Adventure. The word adventure has three syllables or parts. Let’s clap as we say each part of the word, ad-ven-ture.
Scout loves The Greatest Adventure because the author used his imagination to make up the story.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What did you learn about Eliot’s grandfather’s boat?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kind of adventure is Eliot going on? It says he tracked the trails of a wild beast.
How did he track the beast?
Who is the woman in the window? How did Eliot’s mother interrupt, or stop, Eliot’s pretend adventure?
What kind of stories did Eliot’s grandfather tell?
What did Eliot want to do? How does El Capitán show his feelings? Does he look happy or sad?
Why can’t Eliot’s grandfather sail his boat anymore? The sign on the boat says: For Sale. Why do you think he is selling his boat?
What did Eliot do to try to fix the boat? How is he getting ready for a new adventure?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
What did you learn about Eliot’s grandfather’s boat?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The boat was named the Hispaniola.
El Capitán had gone on real adventures in his boat.
The boat was old and broken.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about something they want to be able to do.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What condition was the boat in?
The boat was old and br______ (broken).
The boat was old and broken.
How could Eliot have an adventure on a broken boat?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Verbal and Nonverbal Group Discussion Rules
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Model classroom etiquette and discuss the concept of interrupting. Help children use the phrase “Excuse me” as they act out scenarios when they would like to say something but someone else is speaking. Discuss nonverbal ways of communicating that you want a turn to speak and how to wait politely and not interrupt.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children questions such as what they want to learn next year and what they want to be when they grow up using the “I want to...” sentence frame.
Have children act out something they want to be when they grow up. Ask the rest of the class to guess what they want to be.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Want To... It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves to read informational posters. They always give him new ideas.
The Greatest Adventure and I Want To... show us things we can do. Let’s see if we can find how the two texts are the same.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
We’re ready. What’s next?
section.rac_body-text: Use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you think this boy wants to drive a pretend train or a real train one day? How many cars can you count on his train?
Is this girl having fun making art? What colors is she using?
Why do you think this boy wants to be a doctor when he grows up?

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw a picture of what they want to be when they grow up. If they do not know what they want to be, have them draw something they want to learn more about—how to play an instrument, how to do a cartwheel, or how to ride a bike. Help them plan their work and remind them to persist to finish the project.
Provide a writing prompt about what children would like to do when they grow up as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Although I Want To… and The Greatest Adventure may seem unrelated, help children understand that fictional characters often have ideas that apply to real life. Eliot dreams of his adventures and the child in “be a doctor” may be dreaming about his future. Studies have shown that pretend play can be beneficial for lifelong learning and later success.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Provide children with prompts and have them act out different scenes from The Greatest Adventure as you call it out. For example, say: You are tracking the trails of a wild beast. Allow a few minutes and then interrupt that scene with another one such as: “It’s dinner time!” For each interruption, discuss why it’s sometimes hard to change from one activity to another.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book The Greatest Adventure by Tony Piedra.
This book is a narrative. It tells a story that didn’t happen in real life. The writer imagined it!
This week we read about how happy Eliot was when his grandfather came home. As I read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What did Eliot and his grandfather do together?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you think El Capitán means? What word does it sound like?
Why do you think Eliot took the toy boat and the oar to bed with him? What might have happened to the oar?
Why does Eliot want his grandfather to wake up? What does Eliot want him to do?
What are the concrete giants that Eliot and his grandfather discover?
Stalking means quietly hunting something. What does it mean that Eliot and his grandfather were stalking a paper dragon?
How does Eliot think he can make the boat perfect again?
Why will the boat need a good anchor?
How does an anchor help a boat?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Eliot and his grandfather do together?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about something they will be able to do when they’re older and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What would be your greatest adventure?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For multilingual learners, listening is an important part of gaining knowledge of a language. Invite children whose first language isn’t English to listen to the reading and retelling of the book. Then encourage them to speak to others who have the same first language in order to express their ideas comfortably.
